awd_titl_txt: High Performance SRF Cavities from Improved Superconductors and Production Techniques
awd_abstract_narration: Due to its many successes in science and applications, superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) has become an enabling technology for the accelerator-based sciences such as particle physics, nuclear physics and the materials sciences. Nevertheless, there remain technical and scientific challenges to the full realization of the potential of this technology.  This award to Cornell will provide support for the study of in situ plasma cleaning of SRF cavities as an effective method to recover and/or improve the medium field Q0 of cavities and to systematically study how thermal cycling of a cavity increases its intrinsic quality factor. The group will use temperature mapping systems and existing single and 9-cell cavities for these studies.  Broader impacts of the program are extensive, including impacts across accelerator and materials sciences and student research at the graduate level.

HIGH PERFORMANCE SRF CAVITIES FROM IMPROVED SUPERCONDUCTORS AND PRODUCTION TECHNIQUES

 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

SRF cavities are the most efficient devices to accelerate charged particles. They store electro-magnetic waves with very little energy loss and therefore require relatively little cooling while accelerating charged particles by many millions of Volts. The larger the quality factor Q0, the smaller the energy loss. Cavities are therefore produced from niobium with extreme purity and with surfaces of extreme cleanliness. There are mechanisms, e.g. the collection of dust and other surface impurities, which can decrease Q0 during the operation of an accelerator, where cavities are installed in large cryostats and where they cannot easily be re-cleaned. With this grant we have been exploring (a) in-situ plasma cleaning of SRF cavities to recover Q0 of SRF cavities after degradation during accelerator operation, and (b) systematically studying how thermal cycling of a cavity can increase its Q0. We have used our temperature mapping systems and single and 9-cell cavities that had been provided by previous projects to study these two topics. The results have impact on any SRF project that requires high efficiency, i.e. low cryogenic losses.

The proposed activities contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms that determine the RF surface resistance of superconductors and thereby limit the intrinsic quality factors of SRF cavities. Traditionally, pure niobium has been used for such accelerating systems; and a niobium layer on copper cavities have also been used. More recently, Nb3Sn cavities and nitrogen-doped niobium cavities have been investigated. In this grant we have focused on the production and understanding of low losses in pure niobium and N-doped niobium cavities. The techniques we have developed can equally be applied to other advanced cavity types.

Our results have large impact on all uses of SRF technology where highest Q0’s are essential, especially applications where the cavities operate without break to produce continuous beams. Increasing Q0 of the SRF cavities by a modest factor of two to three would reduce the size of the required, expensive cryogenic refrigerator by a factor of >50% and would allow further optimization, resulting in significant savings in constriction cost, operating cost, and energy consumption. This work will impact proton linacs (PIP-II and PIP-III, neutrino factories, the muon collider, and Accelerator-Driven-Systems (ADS) for energy generation and nuclear waste transmutation), ion linacs (FRIB), and CW operated electron linacs (Energy-Recovery Linacs and SRF driven FELs like LCLS-II), with applications from high-energy physics in the LHeC, nuclear physics in e-RHIC, material and biological sciences in the LCLS-II, and industrial lithography. These activities further provide training of undergraduate and graduate students in cutting edge science, engineering and technology as urgently needed for the U.S. workforce.
